mapNodes.title: Vegetable Garden
mapNodes.description: The Campbell family, who owned Duntroon Estate, allotted a house and a parcel of land to each married worker on the estate. Blundells Cottage is the one of the few remaining cottages from that time period. In addition to the provision of lodgings, the Campbells granted workers a free half day on Saturdays to tend their gardens. Subsequent families also grew their own food for themselves and for sale. This garden bed represents the approximate site of Alice Oldfield's garden. In the 1950s, the Sainsbury family grew potatoes and watermelons on the western side of the house.

mediaItems.caption: The vegetable garden at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The vegetable garden at Blundells Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Girls playing, 1970.
mediaItems.credit: Photo 001202, ACT Heritage Library, Department of Capital Territory Collection

mapNodes.title: Bread Oven
mapNodes.description: This exterior oven was built in an extension to the Cottage completed in 1888 by the Blundell family. Flora Blundell would use this oven to bake bread for the family three times a week. On the other days, the family would eat damper. When she wasn't using it, Flora would let her neighbours, such as Mrs. Mayo, bake for their own families. Thousands of years ago, the local Aboriginal people would also make a type of bread or cake from ground Bogong Moths and Kangaroo Grass.

mediaItems.caption: The bread oven at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The bread oven at Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Ship's Tank
mapNodes.description: Once these tanks had served their purpose on board a ship, they were often purchased by rural households to be used as water tanks. The Blundells had three onsite, which they filled from the Molonglo River.

mediaItems.caption: Ship's tank used as a water tank.
mediaItems.altText: One of the water tanks at Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Rainwater Tank
mapNodes.description: The ubiquitous Australian rainwater tank, used to catch water running off the roof, saved at least some trips to the river. This is the approximate location of the last tank onsite during Alice Oldfield's residence (1930s–⁠40s).

mediaItems.caption: The rainwater tank at the front of Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The rainwater tank at the front of Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Fence Line
mapNodes.description: These posts represent the fence line of the northern boundary of George Blundell's 125 acre leasehold. Property boundary fences were mandatory from the time of the Robertson Land Act of 1864.

mapNodes.title: 1888 Building Line
mapNodes.description: There is a visible change in the stone construction of the building on the western side. The southern section (with the chimney) is an extension built in 1888 and the stonework is not as refined as that of the original building. Note the profile of the original section - it is identical to the crofters cottages of western Scotland, where the original design and the stonemasons themselves came from.

mediaItems.caption: The side of Blundells Cottage showing the difference between the extension and the original building.
mediaItems.altText: The side of Blundells Cottage showing the difference between the extension and the original building.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup showing the detail of the original stonework.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup showing the detail of the original stonework.

mediaItems.caption: Closeup showing the less-refined detail of the extension stonework.
mediaItems.altText: Closeup showing the less-refined detail of the extension stonework.

mediaItems.caption: A Crofters Cottage in Onich, Scotland.
mediaItems.credit: Wikicommons, unknown author, 1903, Leonard A Lauder collection of Raphael Tuck & Sons Postcards https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/
mediaItems.altText: A Crofters Cottage in Onich, Scotland.

mapNodes.title: Artemisia Plant
mapNodes.description: Wormwood (Artemisia arborescens) was a popular plant in the 19th and 20th century because its leaves repel insects.

mediaItems.caption: The wormwood plant outside the Cottage verandah.
mediaItems.altText: The wormwood plant outside the Cottage verandah.

mapNodes.title: Lake Burley Griffin
mapNodes.description: Did you know that Lake Burley Griffin is man-made? It was completed in 1963 after the Molonglo River was dammed. This was not the first significant change to the landscape. The Traditional Custodians of the land experienced major changes to their way of life after European settlement of the area.

mediaItems.caption: Blundells Cottage in the foreground and the High Court under construction in 1978 in the background.
mediaItems.credit: Photo 006158, ACT Heritage Library, Canberra Times Collection
mediaItems.altText: Blundells Cottage in the foreground and the High Court under construction in 1978 in the background.

mediaItems.caption: The Administrative Building (later John Gorton Building) and the National Library of Australia in the background, 1983.
mediaItems.credit: Photo 000210, ACT Heritage Library, Canberra Times Collection
mediaItems.altText: The Administrative Building (later John Gorton Building) and the National Library of Australia in the background, 1983.

mapNodes.title: Acknowledgement of Country
mapNodes.description: Families have occupied this land for thousands of years, long before the Cottage was constructed. The NCA acknowledges the traditional custodians of this land and pays their respects to their elders past, present and emerging.

mediaItems.caption: Ngunnawal rock art from Namadgi National Park about 65km south of Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: Ngunnawal rock art from Namadgi National Park about 65km south of Blundells Cottage.

mapNodes.title: Robert Campbell 1769–1846 - Founder of Duntroon
mapNodes.description: Originally from Scotland, Robert Campbell arrived in Sydney on the Hunter in 1798 as a wealthy merchant. When his ship The Sydney was wrecked, he was compensated in the form of rich, grazing land on the Limestone Plains, now Canberra. He built Duntroon House on his large Duntroon Estate in 1830, the first limestone dwelling in the region. By 1860, George Campbell, Robert's son, and his wife Marrianne Campbell had moved into Duntroon House. They started a major building program on the estate which included workman's cottages for the newly arrived immigrant workers from Britain. Blundells Cottage was made from stone quarried from Black Mountain and Mount Ainslie and was based upon crofters cottages of Western Scotland.

mapNodes.title: Former Site of Cubby
mapNodes.description: During some time in the early 20th century, the verandah of the Cottage was enclosed to create another room. Alice Oldfield would let this room to tenants. The enclosure has since been removed.

mediaItems.caption: A rare photo of the enclosed verandah of the Cottage taken in the 1930s.
mediaItems.altText: A rare photo of the enclosed verandah of the Cottage taken in the 1930s.

mapNodes.title: Former Site of Kennels
mapNodes.description: Harry Oldfield managed the guard dogs for the main gate at the Royal Military College when he occupied the Cottage in the 1930s. We think the kennels may have been located in this spot. The guard dogs were housed and fed at the Cottage and were exchanged at RMC twice daily. After Harry died, Alice and one of Harry’s nephews living with her, took over the duty.

mediaItems.caption: A turkey shed, kennels, haystacks, a small forge, a cow shed and a chicken shed to the right of Blundells Cottage, 1930s.
mediaItems.altText: A turkey shed, kennels, haystacks, a small forge, a cow shed and a chicken shed to the right of Blundells Cottage, 1930s.

mediaItems.caption: David O'Brien on a motorcycle with kennels in the background, 1957.
mediaItems.altText: David O'Brien on a motorcycle with kennels in the background, 1957.

mapNodes.title: Former Site of Beehives
mapNodes.description: George Blundell kept bees and used the rafters in a room in the house (currently presented as Alice Oldfield's kitchen) to hang the comb in calico bags. The honey would drip into containers placed on the brick floor beneath. Could the beehives have been in this spot? To avoid beestings, it's unlikely they were too close to the house!

mapNodes.title: Former Site of Horses
mapNodes.description: In the Blundell era (1874–1933), horses were tethered under a shady tree by the path that led to the front door.

mapNodes.title: Former Site of Alice's Buggy
mapNodes.description: Before cars were readily available, Alice parked her horse-drawn buggy here. Alice lived here in the 30s and 40s.

mediaItems.caption: Horse-drawn buggy, United States, likely taken in the 1930s.
mediaItems.altText: Horse-drawn buggy, United States, likely taken in the 1930s.

mapNodes.title: Former Site of Forge
mapNodes.description: George Blundell may have had a rudimentary forge for quick repairs and the ruins of a ‘shed’ were observed in this spot. Could it be the forge? Other reports say the shed was used as a laundry.

mapNodes.title: Cockatoo and Chooks
mapNodes.description: Alice kept a cockie that would sit on the fence and squawk at visitors to ‘shut the gate’ - to keep the chooks out of the veggie garden.

mapNodes.title: Cypress Pine
mapNodes.description: This Cypress pine is at least 60 years old and may have been planted in the Oldfield era (30s–40s). Cypress pines resist decay, are termite resistant and can be used to make furniture.

mediaItems.caption: The tree out the front of Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The tree out the front of Blundells Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Detail showing the foliage of the tree.
mediaItems.altText: Detail showing the foliage of the tree.

mapNodes.title: Former Site of Outhouse
mapNodes.description: The approximate site of the family outhouse during the Sainsbury period. Outdoor toilets (called 'dunnies') were always some distance from the house, so the smell did not offend anyone. There was an alternative to a long walk on a dark night – look under the beds in the Ginn and Sainsbury rooms.

mediaItems.caption: Outhouse of the Thomas Fulton Memorial Church (South Coree Presbyterian church) at Logie Brae, New South Wales.
mediaItems.altText: Outhouse of the Thomas Fulton Memorial Church (South Coree Presbyterian church) at Logie Brae, New South Wales.

poiNodes.title: Vaccination Certificate
poiNodes.description: William and Mary Ginn and their two boys arrived in Sydney Cove on 23 July 1857 aboard the ship called The Alfred as assisted immigrants. All immigrants were required to be vaccinated against smallpox before their arrival in Australia. The voyage could be a perilous journey and some ships, like the Loch Ard, were wrecked off the coast of Victoria in 1878.

mediaItems.caption: Walter Ginn's vaccination certificate dated 7 November 1854.
mediaItems.altText: Walter Ginn's vaccination certificate dated 7 November 1854.

mediaItems.caption: Wreck of the Loch Ard near Sherbrook River, from Illustrated Sydney News and New South Wales Agriculturist & Grazier, 13 July 1878, p. 13.
mediaItems.credit: Accession Number H2002.150/51 Phillip Doak Collection, State Library of Victoria
mediaItems.altText: Wreck of the Loch Ard near Sherbrook River, from Illustrated Sydney News and New South Wales Agriculturist & Grazier, 13 July 1878, p. 13.

poiNodes.title: Knuckles
poiNodes.description: Knucklebones is a game that has existed for thousands of years across many countries. Commonly, the ankle bones of a sheep are thrown up and caught in different ways. The winner is the first player to successfully complete a series of prescribed throws. In the 1800s, people often handmade their own toys and dolls rather than buying them in a shop. Can you find a game in every room at Blundells Cottage?

poiNodes.title: Inkwell, Bible and Book
poiNodes.description: William and Mary Ginn were the first occupants of the Cottage. Mary's arrival documents record that she was a literate house servant and that William (who could neither read nor write) was a labourer. William and Mary were presented with The Cottagers Family Prayers book on 11 April 1857 by the Rev. Charles Colson with his best wishes. St John the Baptist church would have been an integral part of community life in this district from its consecration in 1845.

mediaItems.caption: Mary Ginn's bible, inkwell and pen.
mediaItems.altText: Mary Ginn's bible, inkwell and pen.

mediaItems.caption: Church of St Johns Canberra, March 18 2007.
mediaItems.altText: Church of St Johns Canberra, March 18 2007.

poiNodes.title: Candle Mould
poiNodes.description: Poorer families had to make candles at home rather than buy them in a shop. By the 1850s, most families used paraffin or beeswax to pour into a mould like this. Can you find a source of light in every room at Blundells Cottage? How have lighting methods changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Iron
poiNodes.description: At home in the 1860s, ironing without electricity was a hard job. Most plain metal irons were heated by a fire or on a stove and they often had a wooden handle so they could be held without getting too hot. At least two irons were needed: one to be in use and one to be re-heated on the fire or stove.

poiNodes.title: Produce Bags
poiNodes.description: Before plasticware or prepackaged goods were available, people used cloth bags when buying and storing food. The bags were re-used and would have been refilled at the Duntroon store that issued supplies to employees. Can you find food containers in every room at Blundells Cottage? How have containers changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Tool Basket
poiNodes.description: William Ginn was a skilled labourer and was the head ploughman on the Duntroon Estate. He was respected by his employer, Charles Campbell, for his quiet manner and diligence. The Robertson Land Acts came into effect not long after William moved into the Cottage, enabling him to select two lots of 40 acres. In his lifetime, William went from a free employee migrant, to a tenant farmer, to a land owner.

mediaItems.caption: Tool basket, short-handled pick and a coffin plane.
mediaItems.altText: Tool basket, short-handled pick and a coffin plane.

mediaItems.caption: Crown Lands Alienation Act of 1861, Government of New South Wales.
mediaItems.altText: Crown Lands Alienation Act of 1861, Government of New South Wales.

poiNodes.title: Bed
poiNodes.description: This is the original bed that the Ginn family brought with them from England to Australia. It would have been stowed away on their ship, The Alfred on their voyage in 1857. Large trunks used to store their belongings during the voyage were then used as bed bases for the children, with straw-filled palliases and bedding placed on top. Have you ever travelled far from home? Journeys can be accompanied by feelings of apprehension, excitement, fear and sadness.

poiNodes.title: Baby's Cot
poiNodes.description: The Ginn family had two boys when they arrived in Australia: Walter and Henry. Baby Gertrude was born before they moved into the Cottage and Agnes some time after. It was common for goods like a cot to be shared in the community if they were no longer needed by a family.

mediaItems.caption: Gertrude Ginn born in Queanbeyan on 21 September, 1865.
mediaItems.altText: Gertrude Ginn born in Queanbeyan on 21 September, 1865.

poiNodes.title: Big Trunk
poiNodes.description: The Ginns would have experienced cramped conditions on their journey from England to Australia on a ship. Clothing and some supplies would have been stored in a canvas bag or small cabin trunk, for ready access, while the remainder of their possessions would have been stored in a trunk such as this. Passengers would have had limited access to their large trunks if weather conditions allowed.

mediaItems.caption: Storage trunk in the Ginn Rooms.
mediaItems.altText: Storage trunk in the Ginn Rooms.

poiNodes.title: Lamp
poiNodes.description: Candle lanterns were effective lights because a gust of wind would not blow them out - particularly useful if venturing to the outhouse in the middle of the night.

poiNodes.title: Sewing Kit
poiNodes.description: Most men and women in the 1860s would have known how to sew. It was cheaper to repair or adjust clothes at home rather than buy them in a shop. Most mothers could make clothes for their children, often out of old, larger clothes. A woman's sewing kit was amongst her most prized possessions and usually contained large and small scissors, thread, needles and a thimble. Can you find a sewing kit in every room at Blundells Cottage? Have sewing kits stayed the same or changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Honey
poiNodes.description: George Blundell kept beehives in the paddock next to the Cottage and used the room which is now displayed as Alice Oldfield's kitchen to extract the honey. After the caps had been sliced off, the combs would be placed in muslin or mosquito net bags and hung from a hook in the exposed rafter over a pan to allow the honey to slowly run out.

poiNodes.title: Sewing Kit and Sewing Machine
poiNodes.description: With eight children and an important role as the local midwife, there is no doubt Flora Blundell would have relied on her oldest daughter to make clothes for the family. The invention, and subsequent widespread availability, of the sewing machine in this era was very welcome.

mediaItems.caption: Flora Susannah Blundell - eldest daughter of Flora and George.
mediaItems.altText: Flora Susannah Blundell - eldest daughter of Flora and George.

mediaItems.caption: Left, Sarah Blundell (wife of Fred Blundell) and her sisters-in-law, Alice (born 1885) and Ada (born 1883) Blundell. Fred, Ada and Alice were the children of George and Flora Blundell.
mediaItems.altText: Left, Sarah Blundell (wife of Fred Blundell) and her sisters-in-law, Alice (born 1885) and Ada (born 1883) Blundell. Fred, Ada and Alice were the children of George and Flora Blundell.

poiNodes.title: Canisters
poiNodes.description: These containers are vermin-proof and keep their contents at a stable temperature. Can you find food containers in every room of the Cottage? How have they changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Lamp
poiNodes.description: Kerosene lamps were the most popular form of lighting in working class households in the 19th century because they were more economical and produced more light than candles. The glass still needed to be cleaned daily and the wick trimmed to ensure minimal smoke and maximum light. Can you find a form of light in every room? How have lights changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Meat Platter
poiNodes.description: This meat platter was a wedding gift from Mrs George Campbell of Duntroon in 1893 for Sarah Winter of Red Hill when she married Samuel Schumack. It is of the famous Willow pattern design and the depression in the platter is to collect the juices when the meat is carved.

poiNodes.title: Washboard
poiNodes.description: Once an article to be washed was wet and soaped, it was then rubbed across the ridges in the metal section of this board to help loosen dirt and stains. This was considered a labour-saving device as it was easier than just rubbing the fabric against itself with your hands. Imagine how much washing had to be done with eight children in the house!

poiNodes.title: Hammocks
poiNodes.description: Hammocks were popular in the 19th and 20th centuries because they were more affordable than beds and they also took up less room. The Blundell boys, who slept in the shed, packed away their hammocks everyday so the space could be used for other purposes.

mediaItems.caption: A young boy in period dress up from the Blundell era, 1963.
mediaItems.credit: Canberra and District Historical Society Collection photograph 2175
mediaItems.altText: A young boy in period dress up from the Blundell era, 1963.

poiNodes.title: Bush Carpentry - Kerosene Cabinet
poiNodes.description: Empty kerosene, oil and biscuit tins were recycled into useful pieces of furniture through the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Some were a simple re-use as a container and others, such as these drawers, were complete pieces of furniture. Some were fancy, like the kindling bin in the next room, but most were made over into needed items as quickly as possible: buckets, watering cans and even shovels.

poiNodes.title: Bush Carpentry - Writing Desk
poiNodes.description: This standing desk was made for Walter Ginn by one of the Blundell family and is made out of packing crates and other recycled timber.

poiNodes.title: Swag Chair
poiNodes.description: This would have been a very useful piece of kit for George Blundell. As bullock driver for the Duntroon Estate he was often on the road, as the round trip to Sydney took six weeks. This chair folds out into a camp bed and, with the addition of a grass or straw-filled palliasse (a thin mattress), would have been a reasonably comfortable bed.

mediaItems.caption: Blundell bullock team with lead bullocks Smut and Smiler. Charles Frederick Blundell in charge.
mediaItems.credit: Canberra and District Historical Society Collection photograph 4840
mediaItems.altText: Blundell bullock team with lead bullocks Smut and Smiler. Charles Frederick Blundell in charge.

poiNodes.title: Gunny Sack and Apron
poiNodes.description: Flora Blundell was born in 1845 and was a Scottish immigrant to Australia. She was the local midwife in the area and would ride on her tall grey horse to women in need. Flora would have had a midwifery kit (in a gunny sack slung across the pommel of her horse) consisting of a clean apron and rudimentary medical equipment. Imagine the change in the landscape she would have experienced as she rode her horse, during her decades in the Cottage.

poiNodes.title: Fireplace
poiNodes.description: In 1888, the Blundell family constructed this slab shed to accommodate their growing family. In this year, their last and eighth child was born. A fabric analysis report from 2017 states that there would have been two rooms in the shed, accommodating a bedroom for some of the children, and a kitchen with a fireplace. Why isn't the fireplace visible onsite anymore? The fireplace is believed to have collapsed in 1962 and replaced with timber slats in 1968.

mediaItems.caption: This photo shows where the fireplace was located inside the Blundell rooms.
mediaItems.altText: This photo shows where the fireplace was located inside the Blundell rooms.

mediaItems.caption: Slab shed and main dwelling plan. The red circles indicate sections of wall that would have been reconstructed in 1968.
mediaItems.credit: Blundells Cottage Slab Shed Fabric Analysis, Pip Giovanelli, 2017
mediaItems.altText: Slab shed and main dwelling plan. The red circles indicate sections of wall that would have been reconstructed in 1968.

poiNodes.title: Scones
poiNodes.description: Alice Oldfield had a small farmlet and would sell eggs, butter, cream and chickens as well as vegetables to the community. She loved to bake and would always have fresh scones, jam and clotted cream to serve to Kevin, a local Canberra boy, when he visited with his mother.

mediaItems.caption: Kevin Mulcahy remembers eating scones with clotted cream as a little boy in Mrs Oldfield's kitchen. Duration: 00:37.
mediaItems.altText: Audio recount of Kevin Mulcahy's memories eating scones as a little boy in Mrs Oldfield's kitchen. Duration: 00:37.

poiNodes.title: Cards
poiNodes.description: The number of young public servants moving to Canberra in the 1950s grew but there was little ‘respectable’ entertainment for them. Alice would hold card evenings in her front room where singles could meet in a chaperoned environment.

mediaItems.caption: Canberrans enjoying the Canberra Olympic Pool late 1950s. Duration: 0:24.
mediaItems.altText: Canberrans enjoying the Canberra Olympic Pool late 1950s. Duration: 0:24.

mediaItems.caption: Cities and Towns - Canberra - Mort Street Industrial Area, 1958.
mediaItems.altText: Cities and Towns - Canberra - Mort Street Industrial Area, 1958.

poiNodes.title: Iron
poiNodes.description: Sometimes called a ‘chuffer’, these irons would be filled with glowing coals from the fire before being pressed onto the fabric. Alice regularly attended St John’s church (like the Ginn family before her) and would add the church linen to her ironing pile.

poiNodes.title: Canisters
poiNodes.description: Bakelite was an early form of plastic which was very popular from the 1920s onward. It was used for jewellery, picnic sets, telephones, radios, electrical switches (look to the left of the stairwell in the Cottage), hair accessories and containers.

poiNodes.title: Lamp
poiNodes.description: Oil and kerosene lamps were still widely available during World War II and into the 1950s as having electricity connected to your house was still uncommon, except in large cities. Can you find different forms of lighting in every room of the Cottage? How has lighting changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Newspaper
poiNodes.description: On 3 September 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Australia was at war. Harry Oldfield died in 1942, three years before the war ended. Alice remained in the Cottage as a widow for another 16 years, letting her rooms for income.

mediaItems.caption: Portrait of Robert Menzies, Luke Monte.
mediaItems.altText: Portrait of Robert Menzies, Luke Monte.

poiNodes.title: Hot Water Bottle
poiNodes.description: Can you guess what this is? It's a ‘bed pig’ or ceramic hot water bottle. Alice's favourite hobby was crochet and you will find several crocheted items in her rooms. She also liked horse racing, playing cards and smoking cigarettes!

mediaItems.caption: ‘Bed pig’ or a ceramic hot water bottle.
mediaItems.altText: ‘Bed pig’ or a ceramic hot water bottle.

poiNodes.title: Shoe Shine
poiNodes.description: Alice's beloved husband Harry died in 1942. He was known in the district for always wearing brown-coloured riding boots when most wore black-coloured. Both his and Alice's shoes would have been polished regularly and cared for so they would last a long time.

poiNodes.title: Stove
poiNodes.description: Alice did not use the original cooking fireplace, with its swinging arm, located in the corner of the room. Instead she had a ‘modern’ Beacon brand stove installed. She used the original cooking fireplace (with its draught) as a tiny cool room or fridge for her meat and dairy products.

poiNodes.title: Exposed Beam
poiNodes.description: The 1888 extension to the Cottage was roofed in corrugated iron. Either then or soon afterwards, corrugated iron was also laid over the original shingles on the rest of the Cottage. Iron had the added advantage of allowing rainwater to be collected, instead of having to draw water from the river. You can see the original shingled roof here.

poiNodes.title: Photo of Alice
poiNodes.description: Alice Oldfield was known as ‘Mrs O’ by most of the community. She was tough, hardworking and generous to those in need. Housing in Canberra was in short supply during and after World War II and Alice would let rooms in her house to boarders, despite not having electricity or running water. Alice also welcomed many babies born in the Cottage, including David O'Brien in 1957.

mediaItems.caption: Earthworks for Commonwealth Gardens from Blundells Cottage, Canberra by Richard Clough.
mediaItems.altText: Earthworks for Commonwealth Gardens from Blundells Cottage, Canberra by Richard Clough.

poiNodes.title: Patchwork Quilt
poiNodes.description: Blundells Cottage was made over as a house museum by the Canberra and District Historical Society in the early 1960s. To mark its opening in 1964, the Canberra Embroiderers Guild made a group patchwork quilt and donated it for display in the Cottage. The names of many of the women who worked on this are stitched into the reverse side.

mediaItems.caption: Mrs Susan Warren with weapons and armour used by the Ned Kelly outlaws, photographed at Blundells Cottage in Canberra, 1976.
mediaItems.altText: Mrs Susan Warren with weapons and armour used by the Ned Kelly outlaws, photographed at Blundells Cottage in Canberra, 1976.

poiNodes.title: Insect Trap
poiNodes.description: Before there was Mortein spray, objects like this were used to trap insects. Honey, sugar water and even liver was placed in the bottom of the trap. Flies, wasps and ants would enter through the broad hole in the base but were unable to find their way out.

poiNodes.title: Sewing Kit
poiNodes.description: The Depression era and then World War II saw a resurgence in making do and mending clothes and linens rather than buying new. ‘Mrs Sew and Sew’ was a popular wartime campaign for household economy.

mediaItems.caption: ‘Mrs Sew and Sew’ campaign from 1944. Video available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I7FaQnqhYBs&t=2s.
mediaItems.altText: ‘Mrs Sew and Sew’ campaign from 1944. Video available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I7FaQnqhYBs&t=2s.

poiNodes.title: Iron
poiNodes.description: Even though electricity was widely available in the 60s in Australia, this Cottage wasn't connected until much later. There have been several inventions to improve ironing without the aid of electricity. This petrol-fired iron is just one of them. It was lit from underneath and a pump was used to build pressure in the tank.

poiNodes.title: Canisters
poiNodes.description: Enamelware was first produced in the USA in the 1870s and continues to be popular today. The durability and low cost of these household items made them popular with lower income families.

poiNodes.title: Lamp
poiNodes.description: Though dangerous (if dropped the glass would explode), these lamps provided as much light as a 60-watt electric globe. After lighting the wick, pressure inside the lamp increases through a pumping action, producing a bright light.

mediaItems.caption: Blundells Cottage, 1965.
mediaItems.credit: Canberra and District Historical Society Collection Photograph 3619

poiNodes.title: Games
poiNodes.description: Without television, the Sainsbury children relied on hobbies, reading and parlour games for amusement. Toys such as dolls for girls and military miniatures for boys were popular in the 1950s and 60s.

poiNodes.title: Darts
poiNodes.description: The Sainsbury family suspended a dartboard above the parents' bed due to the small size of the rooms. After an accident, the children Brian and Susan were only allowed to play darts when their baby sister Wendy was not asleep in the bed underneath.

poiNodes.title: Sink
poiNodes.description: Living in just two rooms without electricity, sewerage or running water must have been difficult. Brian Sainsbury remembers the pride of his father Glenn when he brought home a kitchen sink cupboard for his mother Betty. The water arrived by pitcher and left via a bucket underneath the sink.

poiNodes.title: Cupboard
poiNodes.description: These cabinets were ubiquitous in an Australian house in the first half of the 20th century. Many like this one had metal-lined bread containers in the centre. The metal (sometimes zinc) stopped vermin such as rats from chewing their way through and ruining the family's loaf.

mediaItems.caption: View of the Cottage from Wendouree Drive 1963.
mediaItems.altText: View of the Cottage from Wendouree Drive 1963.

poiNodes.title: Dining Table
poiNodes.description: This china is similar to what the Sainsbury family used while living in the Cottage in the 60s. The children loved Weetbix for breakfast, accompanied by freshly made Sunshine powdered milk. Their father would mix a new batch for them every morning.

poiNodes.title: Radio
poiNodes.description: The Sainsbury family listened to the radio by hooking the power lead up to the battery of Glenn's ute, parked outside the window. The parents listened to the ABC news and dance music on 2CA. The children enjoyed listening to the Argonauts Club, a popular radio show for children.

mediaItems.caption: Argonauts Club Badge and Certificate, 1950s.
mediaItems.credit: State Library of South Australia Collection

poiNodes.title: Toy Planes
poiNodes.description: As a young boy, Brian loved making Airfix model aircraft, including these - a Sopwith Camel, a Lancaster Bomber and a Spitfire. However, he always ran out of patience with the project and never got around to painting them.

poiNodes.title: Posters
poiNodes.description: Betty Sainsbury worked at the Australian War Memorial and would bring home surplus World War II posters for Brian to hang in his bedroom.

poiNodes.title: Sewing Kit
poiNodes.description: Making this style of sewing box was a very popular craft in the 1950s. Wrapping paper, greeting cards or even photographs were cut out in the shapes needed, then sandwiched together between sheets of plastic and crocheted together.

poiNodes.title: Cottage Wall
poiNodes.description: Blundells Cottage was occupied as a home for 100 years and has now existed for 160 years, so has been repainted countless times. Some of those layers of paint are visible here. A forensic paint analysis report found that some of the oldest paint is the pale blue. The Blundell family lived in the Cottage before and after Canberra was chosen as Australia's Federal Capital. Imagine the development of the city they would have seen during their decades in the Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Layers of paint on the wall of the Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: Layers of paint on the wall of the Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Public servants in the Prime Minister's Department, West Block. R G Casey second from right, 1928.
mediaItems.altText: Public servants in the Prime Minister's Department, West Block. R G Casey second from right, 1928.

poiNodes.title: 1. Ginn Rooms
poiNodes.description: William and Mary Ginn and their three children, Walter, Henry and Agnes were the first family to move into the Cottage in about 1860. The Ginns migrated to Australia from England aboard the Alfred in 1857 in search of a better life. William was employed by the Duntroon Estate as the head ploughman and Mary, unlike other wives of workers on the Duntroon Estate, was not employed outside her home. These two rooms are part of the original four-roomed cottage completed in 1860. Can you find what kind of light source the Ginn family may have used in the room before electricity? How did they store their food? How would the Ginn family have mended their clothes? Look out for these kinds of items in the other rooms too, as we travel through time and explore the lives of the families who occupied this Cottage for over 100 years.

mediaItems.caption: Gertrude (standing) and Agnes, daughters of William and Mary Ginn.
mediaItems.credit: Photo courtesy of the Canberra District Historical Society, photograph 345
mediaItems.altText: Gertrude (standing) and Agnes, daughters of William and Mary Ginn.

mediaItems.caption: The Ginn parlour at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The Ginn parlour at Blundells Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: The Ginn bedroom at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The Ginn bedroom at Blundells Cottage.

poiNodes.title: 2. Blundell Rooms
poiNodes.description: George and Flora Blundell, the second occupants of Blundells Cottage, moved in as newlyweds in 1874. George was a bullock driver for the Duntroon Estate and Flora was the local midwife. They raised eight children in the Cottage and had to build this slab shed in 1888 to accommodate them all. How did the Blundells light this space without electricity and how does it compare to other light sources in the Cottage used by families in different time periods? Families in the 1800s would ‘Make Do and Mend’ rather than buying new. What items in this room are recycled?

mediaItems.caption: The first Blundell room in the slab shed.
mediaItems.altText: The first Blundell room in the slab shed.

mediaItems.caption: The second Blundell room in the slab shed.
mediaItems.altText: The second Blundell room in the slab shed.

poiNodes.title: 3. Oldfield Rooms
poiNodes.description: Henry (Harry) Oldfield and his wife, Alice, moved into the Cottage in the early 1930s. When Harry died in 1942, the widow Alice let her rooms to temporary boarders for income and because accommodation was scarce in the growing Capital City. What items in this room may have been mended or recycled in the absence of easily accessible resources? What items show that Alice was a self-sufficient person in the light of adversity?

mediaItems.caption: Alice Matilda Oldfield (1888–1958).
mediaItems.credit: Photo courtesy Mr & Mrs H. Watson, Nowra

mediaItems.caption: The Oldfield kitchen at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The Oldfield kitchen at Blundells Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: The Oldfield bedroom at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The Oldfield bedroom at Blundells Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Scott's Crossing over the Molonglo River, under construction showing Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: Scott's Crossing over the Molonglo River, under construction showing Blundells Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Scott's Crossing over the Molonglo River with Chevrolet motor truck in the foreground
mediaItems.altText: Scott's Crossing over the Molonglo River with Chevrolet motor truck in the foreground

poiNodes.title: 4. Sainsbury Rooms
poiNodes.description: The Sainsbury family rented two rooms of Blundells Cottage from 1958–1961. Glenn and Betty lived here with their three children: Brian, Susan and baby Wendy. Glenn worked as a carpenter on government constructions in Canberra. These rooms were originally added to the Cottage in the late 1880s to house the Blundell's growing family. What did the Sainsbury family do for fun without television? 100 years has passed since the Ginn family lived in the Cottage. How have things stayed the same? How have they changed?

mediaItems.caption: Glenn and Betty Sainsbury on their wedding day, 1950s.
mediaItems.altText: Glenn and Betty Sainsbury on their wedding day, 1950s.

mediaItems.caption: The Sainsbury kitchen at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The Sainsbury kitchen at Blundells Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: The Sainsbury bedroom at Blundells Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: The Sainsbury bedroom at Blundells Cottage.

poiNodes.title: Honey
poiNodes.description: George Blundell kept beehives in the paddock next to the Cottage and used the room which is now displayed as Alice Oldfield's kitchen to extract the honey. After the caps had been sliced off, the combs would be placed in muslin or mosquito net bags and hung from a hook in the exposed rafter over a pan to allow the honey to slowly run out.

poiNodes.title: Sewing Kit and Sewing Machine
poiNodes.description: With eight children and an important role as the local midwife, there is no doubt Flora Blundell would have relied on her oldest daughter to make clothes for the family. The invention, and subsequent widespread availability, of the sewing machine in this era was very welcome.

mediaItems.caption: Flora Susannah Blundell - eldest daughter of Flora and George.
mediaItems.altText: Flora Susannah Blundell - eldest daughter of Flora and George.

mediaItems.caption: Left, Sarah Blundell (wife of Fred Blundell) and her sisters-in-law, Alice (born 1885) and Ada (born 1883) Blundell. Fred, Ada and Alice were the children of George and Flora Blundell.
mediaItems.altText: Left, Sarah Blundell (wife of Fred Blundell) and her sisters-in-law, Alice (born 1885) and Ada (born 1883) Blundell. Fred, Ada and Alice were the children of George and Flora Blundell.

poiNodes.title: Canisters
poiNodes.description: These containers are vermin-proof and keep their contents at a stable temperature. Can you find food containers in every room of the Cottage? How have they changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Lamp
poiNodes.description: Kerosene lamps were the most popular form of lighting in working class households in the 19th century because they were more economical and produced more light than candles. The glass still needed to be cleaned daily and the wick trimmed to ensure minimal smoke and maximum light. Can you find a form of light in every room? How have lights changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Meat Platter
poiNodes.description: This meat platter was a wedding gift from Mrs George Campbell of Duntroon in 1893 for Sarah Winter of Red Hill when she married Samuel Schumack. It is of the famous Willow pattern design and the depression in the platter is to collect the juices when the meat is carved.

poiNodes.title: Washboard
poiNodes.description: Once an article to be washed was wet and soaped, it was then rubbed across the ridges in the metal section of this board to help loosen dirt and stains. This was considered a labour-saving device as it was easier than just rubbing the fabric against itself with your hands. Imagine how much washing had to be done with eight children in the house!

poiNodes.title: Hammocks
poiNodes.description: Hammocks were popular in the 19th and 20th centuries because they were more affordable than beds and they also took up less room. The Blundell boys, who slept in the shed, packed away their hammocks everyday so the space could be used for other purposes.

mediaItems.caption: A young boy in period dress-up from the Blundell era. Taken during a school program in the 1990s.
mediaItems.credit: Canberra and District Historical Society Collection photograph 2175
mediaItems.altText: A young boy in period dress-up from the Blundell era. Taken during a school program in the 1990s.

poiNodes.title: Bush Carpentry - Kerosene Cabinet
poiNodes.description: Empty kerosene, oil and biscuit tins were recycled into useful pieces of furniture through the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Some were a simple re-use as a container and others, such as these drawers, were complete pieces of furniture. Some were fancy, like the kindling bin in the next room, but most were made over into needed items as quickly as possible: buckets, watering cans and even shovels.

poiNodes.title: Bush Carpentry - Writing Desk
poiNodes.description: This standing desk was made for Walter Ginn by one of the Blundell family and is made out of packing crates and other recycled timber.

poiNodes.title: Swag Chair
poiNodes.description: This would have been a very useful piece of kit for George Blundell. As bullock driver for the Duntroon Estate he was often on the road, as the round trip to Sydney took six weeks. This chair folds out into a camp bed and, with the addition of a grass or straw-filled palliasse (a thin mattress), would have been a reasonably comfortable bed.

mediaItems.caption: Blundell bullock team with lead bullocks Smut and Smiler. Charles Frederick Blundell in charge.
mediaItems.credit: Canberra and District Historical Society Collection photograph 4840
mediaItems.altText: Blundell bullock team with lead bullocks Smut and Smiler. Charles Frederick Blundell in charge.

poiNodes.title: Gunny Sack and Apron
poiNodes.description: Flora Blundell was born in 1845 and was a Scottish immigrant to Australia. She was the local midwife in the area and would ride on her tall grey horse to women in need. Flora would have had a midwifery kit (in a gunny sack slung across the pommel of her horse) consisting of a clean apron and rudimentary medical equipment. Imagine the change in the landscape she would have experienced as she rode her horse, during her decades in the Cottage.

poiNodes.title: Scones
poiNodes.description: Alice Oldfield had a small farmlet and would sell eggs, butter, cream and chickens as well as vegetables to the community. She loved to bake and would always have fresh scones, jam and clotted cream to serve to Kevin, a local Canberra boy, when he visited with his mother.

mediaItems.caption: Kevin Mulcahy remembers eating scones with clotted cream as a little boy in Mrs Oldfield's kitchen. Duration: 00:37.
mediaItems.altText: Audio recount of Kevin Mulcahy's memories eating scones as a little boy in Mrs Oldfield's kitchen. Duration: 00:37.

poiNodes.title: Cards
poiNodes.description: The number of young public servants moving to Canberra in the 1950s grew but there was little ‘respectable’ entertainment for them. Alice would hold card evenings in her front room where singles could meet in a chaperoned environment.

mediaItems.caption: Canberrans enjoying the Canberra Olympic Pool late 1950s. Duration: 0:24.
mediaItems.altText: Canberrans enjoying the Canberra Olympic Pool late 1950s. Duration: 0:24.

mediaItems.caption: Cities and Towns - Canberra - Mort Street Industrial Area, 1958.
mediaItems.altText: Cities and Towns - Canberra - Mort Street Industrial Area, 1958.

poiNodes.title: Iron
poiNodes.description: Sometimes called a ‘chuffer’, these irons would be filled with glowing coals from the fire before being pressed onto the fabric. Alice regularly attended St John’s church (like the Ginn family before her) and would add the church linen to her ironing pile.

poiNodes.title: Canisters
poiNodes.description: The Eon company was well known for producing a range of Bakelite products. There is a Bakelite electric power switch located in the bottom right hand edge of the same wall as the window where the canisters are displayed.

mediaItems.caption: Eon ware, an early form of plastic.
mediaItems.altText: Eon ware, an early form of plastic.

poiNodes.title: Lamp
poiNodes.description: Oil and kerosene lamps were still widely available during World War II and into the 1950s as having electricity connected to your house was still uncommon, except in large cities. Can you find different forms of lighting in every room of the Cottage? How has lighting changed over time?

poiNodes.title: Newspaper
poiNodes.description: On 3 September 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Australia was at war. Harry Oldfield died in 1942, three years before the war ended. Alice remained in the Cottage as a widow for another 16 years, letting her rooms for income.

mediaItems.caption: Portrait of Robert Menzies, Luke Monte.
mediaItems.altText: Portrait of Robert Menzies, Luke Monte.

poiNodes.title: Hot Water Bottle
poiNodes.description: Can you guess what this is? It's a ‘bed pig’ or ceramic hot water bottle. Alice's favourite hobby was crochet and you will find several crocheted items in her rooms. She also liked horse racing, playing cards and smoking cigarettes!

mediaItems.caption: ‘Bed pig’ or a ceramic hot water bottle.
mediaItems.altText: ‘Bed pig’ or a ceramic hot water bottle.

poiNodes.title: Shoe Shine
poiNodes.description: Alice's beloved husband Harry died in 1942. He was known in the district for always wearing brown-coloured riding boots when most wore black-coloured. Both his and Alice's shoes would have been polished regularly and cared for so they would last a long time.

poiNodes.title: Stove
poiNodes.description: Alice did not use the original cooking fireplace, with its swinging arm, located in the corner of the room. Instead she had a ‘modern’ Beacon brand stove installed. She used the original cooking fireplace (with its draught) as a tiny cool room or fridge for her meat and dairy products.

poiNodes.title: Exposed Beam
poiNodes.description: The 1888 extension to the Cottage was roofed in corrugated iron. Either then or soon afterwards, corrugated iron was also laid over the original shingles on the rest of the Cottage. Iron had the added advantage of allowing rainwater to be collected, instead of having to draw water from the river. You can see the original shingled roof here.

poiNodes.title: Photo of Alice
poiNodes.description: Alice Oldfield was known as ‘Mrs O’ by most of the community. She was tough, hardworking and generous to those in need. Housing in Canberra was in short supply during and after World War II and Alice would let rooms in her house to boarders, despite not having electricity or running water. Alice also welcomed many babies born in the Cottage, including David O'Brien in 1957.

mediaItems.caption: Earthworks for Commonwealth Gardens from Blundells Cottage, Canberra by Richard Clough.
mediaItems.altText: Earthworks for Commonwealth Gardens from Blundells Cottage, Canberra by Richard Clough.

poiNodes.title: Patchwork Quilt
poiNodes.description: Blundells Cottage was made over as a house museum by the Canberra and District Historical Society in the early 1960s. To mark its opening in 1964, the Canberra Embroiderers Guild made a group patchwork quilt and donated it for display in the Cottage. The names of many of the women who worked on this are stitched into the reverse side.

poiNodes.title: Insect Trap
poiNodes.description: Before there was Mortein spray, objects like this were used to trap insects. Honey, sugar water and even liver was placed in the bottom of the trap. Flies, wasps and ants would enter through the broad hole in the base but were unable to find their way out.

poiNodes.title: Sewing Kit
poiNodes.description: The Depression era and then World War II saw a resurgence in making do and mending clothes and linens rather than buying new. ‘Mrs Sew and Sew’ was a popular wartime campaign for household economy.

mediaItems.caption: ‘Mrs Sew and Sew’ campaign from 1944. Video available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I7FaQnqhYBs&t=2s.
mediaItems.altText: ‘Mrs Sew and Sew’ campaign from 1944. Video available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I7FaQnqhYBs&t=2s.

poiNodes.title: Iron
poiNodes.description: Even though electricity was widely available in the 60s in Australia, this Cottage wasn't connected until much later. There have been several inventions to improve ironing without the aid of electricity. This petrol-fired iron is just one of them. It was lit from underneath and a pump was used to build pressure in the tank.

poiNodes.title: Canisters
poiNodes.description: Enamelware was first produced in the USA in the 1870s and continues to be popular today. The durability and low cost of these household items made them popular with lower income families.

poiNodes.title: Lamp
poiNodes.description: Though dangerous (if dropped the glass would explode), these lamps provided as much light as a 60-watt electric globe. After lighting the wick, pressure inside the lamp increases through a pumping action, producing a bright light.

mediaItems.caption: Blundells Cottage, 1965.
mediaItems.credit: Canberra and District Historical Society Collection Photograph 3619

poiNodes.title: Games
poiNodes.description: Without television, the Sainsbury children relied on hobbies, reading and parlour games for amusement. Toys such as dolls for girls and military miniatures for boys were popular in the 1950s and 60s.

poiNodes.title: Darts
poiNodes.description: The Sainsbury family suspended a dartboard above the parents' bed due to the small size of the rooms. After an accident, the children Brian and Susan were only allowed to play darts when their baby sister Wendy was not asleep in the bed underneath.

poiNodes.title: Sink
poiNodes.description: Living in just two rooms without electricity, sewerage or running water must have been difficult. Brian Sainsbury remembers the pride of his father Glenn when he brought home a kitchen sink cupboard for his mother Betty. The water arrived by pitcher and left via a bucket underneath the sink.

poiNodes.title: Cupboard
poiNodes.description: These cabinets were ubiquitous in an Australian house in the first half of the 20th century. Many like this one had metal-lined bread containers in the centre. The metal (sometimes zinc) stopped vermin such as rats from chewing their way through and ruining the family's loaf.

mediaItems.caption: View of the Cottage from Wendouree Drive 1963.
mediaItems.altText: View of the Cottage from Wendouree Drive 1963.

poiNodes.title: Dining Table
poiNodes.description: This china is similar to what the Sainsbury family used while living in the Cottage in the 50s. The children loved Weetbix for breakfast, accompanied by freshly made Sunshine powdered milk. Their father would mix a new batch for them every morning.

poiNodes.title: Radio
poiNodes.description: The Sainsbury family listened to the radio by hooking the power lead up to the battery of Glenn's ute, parked outside the window. The parents listened to the ABC news and dance music on 2CA. The children enjoyed listening to the Argonauts Club, a popular radio show for children.

mediaItems.caption: Argonauts Club Badge and Certificate, 1950s.
mediaItems.credit: State Library of South Australia Collection

poiNodes.title: Toy Planes
poiNodes.description: As a young boy, Brian loved making Airfix model aircraft, including these - a Sopwith Camel, a Lancaster Bomber and a Spitfire. However, he always ran out of patience with the project and never got around to painting them.

poiNodes.title: Posters
poiNodes.description: Betty Sainsbury worked at the Australian War Memorial and would bring home surplus World War II posters for Brian to hang in his bedroom.

poiNodes.title: Sewing Kit
poiNodes.description: Making this style of sewing box was a very popular craft in the 1950s. Wrapping paper, greeting cards or even photographs were cut out in the shapes needed, then sandwiched between sheets of plastic and crocheted together.

poiNodes.title: Cottage Wall
poiNodes.description: Blundells Cottage was occupied as a home for 100 years and has now existed for 160 years, so has been repainted countless times. Some of those layers of paint are visible here. A forensic paint analysis report found that some of the oldest paint is the pale blue. The Blundell family lived in the Cottage before and after Canberra was chosen as Australia's Federal Capital. Imagine the development of the city they would have seen during their decades in the Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Layers of paint on the wall of the Cottage.
mediaItems.altText: Layers of paint on the wall of the Cottage.

mediaItems.caption: Public servants in the Prime Minister's Department, West Block. R G Casey second from right, 1928.
mediaItems.altText: Public servants in the Prime Minister's Department, West Block. R G Casey second from right, 1928.
